### Basic Assignment

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# String assignment
name="Alice"
greeting="Hello, World"
path="/usr/local/bin"

# Numbers (still stored as strings internally)
count=42
price=19.99

# Command output (command substitution)
current_date=$(date +%Y-%m-%d)
current_dir=$(pwd)
file_count=$(ls | wc -l)

# Arithmetic assignment
((sum = 5 + 3))
((product = 4 * 7))

# Using let (alternative)
let "difference = 10 - 3"
```

### Why Use `${var}` and `"${var}"`?

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

fruit="apple"

# Problem: ambiguity
echo "$fruitpie"      # Tries to find variable 'fruitpie' â†’ empty!
echo "${fruit}pie"    # Output: applepie âœ“

# Problem: word splitting
filename="my document.txt"

# Without quotes - BROKEN (splits into 2 arguments)
touch $filename       # Creates 2 files: "my" and "document.txt"

# With quotes - CORRECT
touch "$filename"     # Creates 1 file: "my document.txt"
```

### readonly and declare

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Constants (cannot be changed)
readonly PI=3.14159
readonly CONFIG_FILE="/etc/myapp/config.conf"

PI=3.14  # Error: PI: readonly variable

# declare options
declare -r CONSTANT="immutable"     # readonly
declare -i number=42                # integer (arithmetic context)
declare -l lowercase="HELLO"        # convert to lowercase â†’ "hello"
declare -u uppercase="hello"        # convert to uppercase â†’ "HELLO"

echo "$lowercase"   # Output: hello
echo "$uppercase"   # Output: HELLO

# Integer declaration enables arithmetic
declare -i num=5
num=num+3           # Works! num is now 8 (no need for $(( )))
echo "$num"         # Output: 8
```

### Working with Environment Variables

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# View all environment variables
env
printenv

# View specific environment variable
echo "$HOME"
echo "$PATH"
echo "$USER"

# Create local variable (only in current shell)
my_local="I'm local"

# Export to make it environment variable (inherited by child processes)
export MY_ENV_VAR="I'm exported"

# One-liner: declare and export
export DATABASE_URL="postgres://localhost:5432/mydb"

# Export existing variable
secret_key="abc123"
export secret_key

# Remove from environment
unset MY_ENV_VAR
```

### Demonstration

```bash
# --- parent.sh ---
#!/usr/bin/env bash

local_var="I'm local"
export exported_var="I'm exported"

echo "Parent - local_var: $local_var"
echo "Parent - exported_var: $exported_var"

# Run child script
./child.sh
```

```bash
# --- child.sh ---
#!/usr/bin/env bash

echo "Child - local_var: $local_var"         # Empty!
echo "Child - exported_var: $exported_var"   # Works!
```

```
Output:
Parent - local_var: I'm local
Parent - exported_var: I'm exported
Child - local_var: 
Child - exported_var: I'm exported
```

### `$@` vs `$*` â€” The Important Difference

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# save as: args_demo.sh

echo "Using \$* (without quotes):"
for arg in $*; do
    echo "  [$arg]"
done

echo ""
echo "Using \$@ (without quotes):"
for arg in $@; do
    echo "  [$arg]"
done

echo ""
echo 'Using "$*" (quoted - single string):'
for arg in "$*"; do
    echo "  [$arg]"
done

echo ""
echo 'Using "$@" (quoted - preserves arguments):'  # â† BEST PRACTICE
for arg in "$@"; do
    echo "  [$arg]"
done
```

```bash
$ ./args_demo.sh "hello world" foo bar

Using $* (without quotes):
  [hello]
  [world]
  [foo]
  [bar]

Using $@ (without quotes):
  [hello]
  [world]
  [foo]
  [bar]

Using "$*" (quoted - single string):
  [hello world foo bar]

Using "$@" (quoted - preserves arguments):
  [hello world]      â† Preserved as single argument!
  [foo]
  [bar]
```

### Exit Status (`$?`)

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Every command returns an exit status
# 0 = success, non-zero = failure

ls /tmp
echo "Exit status: $?"   # 0 (success)

ls /nonexistent_directory 2>/dev/null
echo "Exit status: $?"   # 2 (failure)

# Common exit codes
# 0   - Success
# 1   - General errors
# 2   - Misuse of shell command
# 126 - Command not executable
# 127 - Command not found
# 128+n - Killed by signal n

# Use in conditionals
if grep -q "pattern" file.txt; then
    echo "Pattern found"   # grep returns 0
else
    echo "Pattern not found"   # grep returns 1
fi

# Or use && and ||
command && echo "Success" || echo "Failure"
```

### Practical Example: Script with Arguments

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# save as: greet.sh

set -euo pipefail

# Check argument count
if [[ $# -lt 1 ]]; then
    echo "Usage: $0 <name> [greeting]"
    echo "Example: $0 Alice 'Good morning'"
    exit 1
fi

name="$1"
greeting="${2:-Hello}"   # Default to "Hello" if not provided

echo "$greeting, $name!"
echo ""
echo "--- Debug Info ---"
echo "Script name: $0"
echo "Number of args: $#"
echo "All args: $@"
echo "Process ID: $$"
```

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Creating arrays
fruits=("apple" "banana" "cherry" "date")
numbers=(1 2 3 4 5)
mixed=("hello" 42 "world")

# Alternative: declare
declare -a my_array=("one" "two" "three")

# Empty array, then add elements
files=()
files+=("file1.txt")
files+=("file2.txt")
files+=("file3.txt")

# Access elements
echo "${fruits[0]}"      # apple
echo "${fruits[2]}"      # cherry
echo "${fruits[-1]}"     # date (last element)

# All elements
echo "${fruits[@]}"      # apple banana cherry date
echo "${fruits[*]}"      # apple banana cherry date

# Array length
echo "${#fruits[@]}"     # 4

# All indices
echo "${!fruits[@]}"     # 0 1 2 3

# Slice (offset:length)
echo "${fruits[@]:1:2}"  # banana cherry (start at 1, take 2)

# Modify element
fruits[1]="blueberry"
echo "${fruits[@]}"      # apple blueberry cherry date

# Append
fruits+=("elderberry")

# Delete element (leaves gap!)
unset 'fruits[2]'
echo "${fruits[@]}"      # apple blueberry date elderberry
echo "${!fruits[@]}"     # 0 1 3 4 (index 2 is gone!)
```

### Iterating Over Arrays

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

files=("report.pdf" "data file.csv" "image.png")

# WRONG - breaks on spaces
for file in ${files[@]}; do
    echo "Processing: $file"
done
# Output:
# Processing: report.pdf
# Processing: data        â† BROKEN!
# Processing: file.csv    â† BROKEN!
# Processing: image.png

# CORRECT - always quote!
for file in "${files[@]}"; do
    echo "Processing: $file"
done
# Output:
# Processing: report.pdf
# Processing: data file.csv  â† Correct!
# Processing: image.png

# With index
for i in "${!files[@]}"; do
    echo "[$i]: ${files[$i]}"
done
```

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# MUST declare with -A
declare -A patient

# Assign values
patient[id]="P001"
patient[name]="John Doe"
patient[modality]="CT"
patient[body_part]="chest"

# Or inline (Bash 4+)
declare -A config=(
    [host]="localhost"
    [port]="5432"
    [database]="radiology_db"
)

# Access
echo "${patient[name]}"         # John Doe
echo "${config[host]}"          # localhost

# All values
echo "${patient[@]}"            # P001 John Doe CT chest (unordered!)

# All keys
echo "${!patient[@]}"           # id name modality body_part

# Length (number of keys)
echo "${#patient[@]}"           # 4

# Check if key exists
if [[ -v patient[name] ]]; then
    echo "Name is set"
fi

# Iterate
for key in "${!patient[@]}"; do
    echo "$key: ${patient[$key]}"
done

# Delete a key
unset 'patient[body_part]'
```

### Practical Example: DICOM Metadata

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

declare -A dicom_tags=(
    [PatientName]="0010,0010"
    [PatientID]="0010,0020"
    [StudyDate]="0008,0020"
    [Modality]="0008,0060"
    [BodyPartExamined]="0018,0015"
)

# Look up a tag
tag_name="Modality"
echo "$tag_name has DICOM tag: ${dicom_tags[$tag_name]}"

# List all tags
echo "Available DICOM tags:"
for name in "${!dicom_tags[@]}"; do
    printf "  %-20s %s\n" "$name" "${dicom_tags[$name]}"
done
```

### Substring Extraction

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

filename="patient_ct_scan_001.dcm"

echo "${#filename}"           # 23 (length)
echo "${filename:0:7}"        # patient (first 7)
echo "${filename:8:7}"        # ct_scan
echo "${filename: -3}"        # dcm (last 3, note space before -)
echo "${filename:0:-4}"       # patient_ct_scan_001 (remove last 4)
```

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

path="/home/user/documents/report.txt"

# Replace first occurrence
echo "${path/user/admin}"     # /home/admin/documents/report.txt

# Replace all occurrences
text="foo bar foo baz foo"
echo "${text//foo/XXX}"       # XXX bar XXX baz XXX

# Replace at start/end
filename="test_file_test.txt"
echo "${filename/#test/exam}" # exam_file_test.txt
echo "${filename/%txt/md}"    # test_file_test.md

# Delete pattern (replace with nothing)
echo "${path//\//}"           # homeusersdocumentsreport.txt
```

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Get filename (remove directory path)
echo "${filepath##*/}"        # scan_001.dcm

# Get directory (remove filename)
echo "${filepath%/*}"         # /home/user/data

# Get extension
echo "${filepath##*.}"        # dcm

# Remove extension
echo "${filepath%.*}"         # /home/user/data/scan_001

# Get filename without extension
filename="${filepath##*/}"    # scan_001.dcm
echo "${filename%.*}"         # scan_001

# Handle multiple extensions
archive="backup.tar.gz"
echo "${archive%.*}"          # backup.tar (shortest - one ext)
echo "${archive%%.*}"         # backup (longest - all ext)
```

### Case Conversion (Bash 4+)

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

text="Hello World"

# Lowercase
echo "${text,,}"              # hello world (all)
echo "${text,}"               # hello World (first char only)

# Uppercase
echo "${text^^}"              # HELLO WORLD (all)
echo "${text^}"               # Hello World (first char only)

# Toggle case (Bash 4+)
echo "${text~~}"              # hELLO wORLD

# Practical use
read -p "Enter modality: " modality
modality="${modality^^}"      # Normalize to uppercase
echo "Looking for $modality scans..."
```

```bash
echo "Output: $OUTPUT_DIR"

# Error if required variable not set
: "${API_KEY:?ERROR: API_KEY must be set}"

# Practical example: Configuration with defaults
config_file="${CONFIG_FILE:-/etc/myapp/config.conf}"

max_retries="${MAX_RETRIES:-3}"

echo "Config: $config_file"
echo "Log level: $log_level"
echo "Max retries: $max_retries"
```

### Practical String Example: Filename Processing

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Process DICOM filenames

process_dicom() {
    local filepath="$1"
    
    # Extract components
    local dir="${filepath%/*}"
    local filename="${filepath##*/}"
    local basename="${filename%.*}"
    local extension="${filename##*.}"
    
    # Parse naming convention: PatientID_Modality_SeriesNum.dcm
    # Example: P12345_CT_001.dcm
    local patient_id="${basename%%_*}"
    local rest="${basename#*_}"
    local modality="${rest%%_*}"
    local series="${rest##*_}"
    
    echo "File: $filepath"
    echo "  Directory:  $dir"
    echo "  Filename:   $filename"
    echo "  Patient ID: $patient_id"
    echo "  Modality:   $modality"
    echo "  Series:     $series"
    echo ""
}

# Test
process_dicom "/data/dicom/P12345_CT_001.dcm"
process_dicom "/data/dicom/P67890_MRI_003.dcm"
```
